action.action-desc: Mr. Katko (for himself, Mr. Thompson of Mississippi, Mr. Guest, Mr. Torres of New York, Mr. Meijer, Mr. Correa, Mr. Higgins of Louisiana, Ms. Barragán, Mrs. Cammack, Mrs. Demings, Mr. Gimenez, Mrs. Watson Coleman, Mr. Garbarino, Ms. Clarke of New York, Mr. Pfluger, and Ms. Slotkin) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, and in addition to the Committees on Homeland Security, and Ways and Means, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To establish a Department of Homeland Security Center for Countering Human Trafficking, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Countering Human Trafficking Act of 2022.
It is the sense of Congress that—

paragraph.text: the victim-centered approach must become universally understood, adopted, and practiced;
criminal justice efforts must increase the focus on, and adeptness at, investigating and prosecuting forced labor cases;
corporations must eradicate forced labor from their supply chains;
the Department of Homeland Security must lead by example—

subparagraph.text: by ensuring that its government supply chain of contracts and procurement are not tainted by forced labor; and
by leveraging all of its authorities against the importation of goods produced with forced labor; and

paragraph.text: human trafficking training, awareness, identification, and screening efforts—

subparagraph.text: are a necessary first step for prevention, protection, and enforcement; and
should be evidence-based to be most effective.

section.header: Department of Homeland Security Center for Countering Human Trafficking

paragraph.text: The Secretary of Homeland Security shall operate, within U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement’s Homeland Security Investigations, the Center for Countering Human Trafficking (referred to in this Act as CCHT).

The purpose of CCHT shall be to serve at the forefront of the Department of Homeland Security’s unified global efforts to counter human trafficking through law enforcement operations and victim protection, prevention, and awareness programs.
Homeland Security Investigations shall—

subparagraph.text: maintain a concept of operations that identifies CCHT participants, funding, core functions, and personnel; and
update such concept of operations, as needed, to accommodate its mission and the threats to such mission.
The Secretary of Homeland Security shall appoint a CCHT Director, who shall—

clause.text: be a member of the Senior Executive Service; and
serve as the Department of Homeland Security’s representative on human trafficking.

subparagraph.text: Subject to appropriations, the Secretary of Homeland Security shall ensure that CCHT is staffed with at least 45 employees in order to maintain continuity of effort, subject matter expertise, and necessary support to the Department of Homeland Security, including—

clause.text: employees who are responsible for the Continued Presence Program and other victim protection duties;
employees who are responsible for training, including curriculum development, and public awareness and education;
employees who are responsible for stakeholder engagement, Federal interagency coordination, multilateral partnerships, and policy;
employees who are responsible for public relations, human resources, evaluation, data analysis and reporting, and information technology;
special agents and criminal analysts necessary to accomplish its mission of combating human trafficking and the importation of goods produced with forced labor; and

subsection.text: The CCHT Director shall operate, within CCHT, an Operations Unit, which shall, at a minimum—

paragraph.text: support criminal investigations of human trafficking (including sex trafficking and forced labor)—

subparagraph.text: by developing, tracking, and coordinating leads; and

paragraph.text: augment the enforcement of the prohibition on the importation of goods produced with forced labor through civil and criminal authorities;

coordinate a Department-wide effort to conduct procurement audits and enforcement actions, including suspension and debarment, in order to mitigate the risk of human trafficking throughout Department acquisitions and contracts; and
support all CCHT enforcement efforts with intelligence by conducting lead development, lead validation, case support, strategic analysis, and data analytics.

subsection.text: The CCHT Director shall operate, within CCHT, a Protection and Awareness Programs Unit, which shall—

paragraph.text: incorporate a victim-centered approach throughout Department of Homeland Security policies, training, and practices;
operate a comprehensive Continued Presence program;
conduct, review, and assist with Department of Homeland Security human trafficking training, screening, and identification tools and efforts;

operate the Blue Campaign’s nationwide public awareness effort and any other awareness efforts needed to encourage victim identification and reporting to law enforcement and to prevent human trafficking; and

coordinate external engagement, including training and events, regarding human trafficking with critical partners, including survivors, nongovernmental organizations, corporations, multilateral entities, law enforcement agencies, and other interested parties.

subsection.text: The CCHT Director, in conjunction with the Science and Technology Directorate Office of Science and Engineering, shall develop a strategy and proposal to modify systems and processes throughout the Department of Homeland Security that are related to CCHT’s mission in order to—

paragraph.text: decrease the response time to access victim protections;
accelerate lead development;
advance the identification of human trafficking characteristics and trends;
fortify the security and protection of sensitive information;
apply analytics to automate manual processes; and
provide artificial intelligence and machine learning to increase system capabilities and enhance data availability, reliability, comparability, and verifiability.

subsection.text: Upon the completion of the strategy and proposal under subsection (a), the Secretary of Homeland Security shall submit a summary of the strategy and plan for executing the strategy to—

paragraph.text: the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs of the Senate; and
the Committee on Homeland Security of the House of Representatives.

subsection.header: Information sharing To facilitate reports and analysis
subsection.text: Each subagency of the Department of Homeland Security shall share with CCHT—

paragraph.text: any information needed by CCHT to develop the strategy and proposal required under section 4(a); and
any additional data analysis to help CCHT better understand the issues surrounding human trafficking.

subsection.text: Not later than 1 year after the date of the enactment of this Act, the CCHT Director shall submit a report to Congress that identifies any legislation that is needed to facilitate the Department of Homeland Security’s mission to end human trafficking.

section.header: Transfer of other functions related to human trafficking

subsection.text: The functions and resources of the Blue Campaign located within the Office of Partnership and Engagement on the day before the date of the enactment of this Act are hereby transferred to CCHT.

paragraph.text: Not later than 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Homeland Security may transfer the functions and resources of any component, directorate, or other office of the Department of Homeland Security related to combating human trafficking to the CCHT.

Not later than 30 days before executing any transfer authorized under paragraph (1), the Secretary of Homeland Security shall notify the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs of the Senate and the Committee on Homeland Security of the House of Representatives of such planned transfer.

section.text: In addition to amounts otherwise authorized to be appropriated, there is authorized to be appropriated to the Secretary of Homeland Security to carry out this Act $14,000,000, which shall remain available until expended.
